title: Rheumatoid Factor Test: What to Know
author: Debra Fulghum Bruce, PhD, Kendall K. Morgan

sections.heading: What Is the Rheumatoid Factor Test?
content: A rheumatoid factor test, or RF test, is a blood test to look for rheumatoid factors in your blood.

If you have symptoms of rheumatoid arthritis , such as pain, swelling, and stiff joints, your doctor may use the rheumatoid factor blood test to help diagnose it. When rheumatoid factor is in your bloodstream, it will help your doctor know if you have rheumatoid arthritis and how severe it is. The test also helps your doctor tell the difference between rheumatoid arthritis and other types of arthritis , as well as other conditions.

High levels of rheumatoid factor can show up in people with severe rheumatoid arthritis. But even if the test results show you have a high level of it, your doctor will want to do other tests before they make a diagnosis. They will examine you and may order other types of lab tests, such as X-rays, a magnetic resonance imaging ( MRI ) scan, an ultrasound , or other scans.
(Photo Credit: Moment/Getty Images)

If you have symptoms of rheumatoid arthritis , such as pain, swelling, and stiff joints, your doctor may use the rheumatoid factor blood test to help diagnose it. The test also helps your doctor tell the difference between rheumatoid arthritis and other types of arthritis , as well as other conditions.

High levels of rheumatoid factor can show up in people with severe rheumatoid arthritis. But even if the test results show you have a high level of it, your doctor will want to do other tests before they make a diagnosis. They will examine you and may order other types of lab tests, such as X-rays, a magnetic resonance imaging ( MRI ) scan, an ultrasound , or other scans.
(Photo Credit: Moment/Getty Images)

sections.heading: What Is Rheumatoid Factor (RF)?
content: Rheumatoid factors are antibody proteins your immune system makes. Normally, your immune system makes antibodies to attack infectious invaders to keep you well. But rheumatoid factor antibodies are made by mistake and don't have a specific or known target. As a result, they may attack your own cells or tissues to cause rheumatoid arthritis, an autoimmune condition that causes joint damage and pain, or another autoimmune condition.

content_blocks.text: Rheumatoid factors are antibody proteins your immune system makes. Normally, your immune system makes antibodies to attack infectious invaders to keep you well. But rheumatoid factor antibodies are made by mistake and don't have a specific or known target. As a result, they may attack your own cells or tissues to cause rheumatoid arthritis, an autoimmune condition that causes joint damage and pain, or another autoimmune condition.

sections.heading: What Is the Rheumatoid Factor Test Used For?
content: Your doctor may order a rheumatoid factor test if you have signs or symptoms that may be related to high levels of rheumatoid factor. But you could have high RF levels without any symptoms you notice. You could have high RF levels with no clear reason or cause. Some symptoms that might make your doctor wonder about your RF levels include:
Rheumatoid factor tests may be used to test for rheumatoid arthritis . But an RF test also can help to diagnose other autoimmune conditions such as:
RF tests may also be used to diagnose a chronic infection such as hepatitis C, tuberculosis (TB), or endocarditis.
bullets: Joint pain
Other pain
Swelling
Changes in your skin color
Warmth or heat in your joints
Fatigue
Fevers
Sjogren's syndrome
Juvenile idiopathic arthritis
Lupus scleroderma
Mixed connective tissue disease

sections.heading: RF Test and Rheumatoid Arthritis Diagnosis
content: Nobody knows what the antibodies known as rheumatoid factor do when they're in the blood of healthy people. It's not clear exactly what they do when you have rheumatoid arthritis either. Most people with this form of arthritis will have RF in their blood. But you may not have a positive RF test if your rheumatoid arthritis is in an early stage. RF levels might change over time along with your disease activity. But even people who are in remission after treatment for their arthritis can still have high RF levels.

Rheumatoid factor also may be present in many or most people with other autoimmune conditions. So the presence of RF alone doesn't mean that you have rheumatoid arthritis. You may not have signs of any autoimmune condition. Or you could have another condition that's affecting your immune system.

content_blocks.text: Nobody knows what the antibodies known as rheumatoid factor do when they're in the blood of healthy people. Rheumatoid factor also may be present in many or most people with other autoimmune conditions. So the presence of RF alone doesn't mean that you have rheumatoid arthritis. You may not have signs of any autoimmune condition. Or you could have another condition that's affecting your immune system.

sections.heading: How Is the RF Test Done?
content: A rheumatoid factor test is similar to a blood draw or any other blood test. Your doctor will use a needle to collect blood from a vein, and then send your blood sample to a lab for testing. You should let your doctor know if you have trouble with needles or having blood drawn. Your doctor, nurse, or other provider will:
bullets: Clean the part of your arm where they'll place the needle
Tie an elastic band around your upper arm
Possibly ask you to make a fist or squeeze to help blood flow
Insert a needle into your arm
Collect your blood into a vial
Remove the needle and put a bandage over the spot

content_blocks.text: A rheumatoid factor test is similar to a blood draw or any other blood test. Your doctor will use a needle to collect blood from a vein, and then send your blood sample to a lab for testing. You should let your doctor know if you have trouble with needles or having blood drawn. Your doctor, nurse, or other provider will:
associated_bullets: Clean the part of your arm where they'll place the needle
Tie an elastic band around your upper arm
Possibly ask you to make a fist or squeeze to help blood flow
Insert a needle into your arm
Collect your blood into a vial
Remove the needle and put a bandage over the spot

content: An RF test shouldn't hurt a lot, but you may feel a pinch or mild discomfort. It's best to stay relaxed and breathe. A rheumatoid factor test doesn't come with much risk. But you could feel a little dizzy or lightheaded. You may want to take a minute to relax before getting up.
Your provider will send your sample off for testing to see how high your RF levels are.

sections.heading: Preparing for Your Rheumatoid Factor Blood Test
content: You won’t have to do anything to prepare. Some people are more sensitive than others about having blood taken. If you have questions, talk to your doctor before the test. If you feel uneasy, faint, or nauseated, let your doctor know.

content_blocks.text: You won’t have to do anything to prepare. Some people are more sensitive than others about having blood taken. If you have questions, talk to your doctor before the test. If you feel uneasy, faint, or nauseated, let your doctor know.

sections.heading: Preparing for Your Rheumatoid Factor Blood Test
content: You won’t have to do anything to prepare. Some people are more sensitive than others about having blood taken. If you have questions, talk to your doctor before the test. If you feel uneasy, faint, or nauseated, let your doctor know.

content_blocks.text: You won’t have to do anything to prepare. Some people are more sensitive than others about having blood taken. If you have questions, talk to your doctor before the test. If you feel uneasy, faint, or nauseated, let your doctor know.

sections.heading: Rheumatoid Factor Test Results
content: Test results, along with your physical exam , other tests, and your history of symptoms, give your doctor more information and may also help show how serious your rheumatoid arthritis or other autoimmune condition might be.

content_blocks.text: Test results, along with your physical exam , other tests, and your history of symptoms, give your doctor more information and may also help show how serious your rheumatoid arthritis or other autoimmune condition might be.

content: Your test result will tell you how much RF is in each milliliter of your blood. A normal amount is under 20 units. Your doctor may also say that your test result is positive or negative. A negative result means you have a normal RF level. A positive test result means your rheumatoid factor levels are higher than they should be.

Remember, sometimes the rheumatoid factor is also found in the blood of healthy people. And it’s found in people with other immune system conditions like lupus and Sjogren's syndrome. People with chronic infections like viral hepatitis can have it too.

content_blocks.text: Your test result will tell you how much RF is in each milliliter of your blood. A normal amount is under 20 units. Your doctor may also say that your test result is positive or negative. A negative result means you have a normal RF level. A positive test result means your rheumatoid factor levels are higher than they should be.

Remember, sometimes the rheumatoid factor is also found in the blood of healthy people. And it’s found in people with other immune system conditions like lupus and Sjogren's syndrome. People with chronic infections like viral hepatitis can have it too.

sections.heading: Rheumatoid Factor Test Follow-Up
content: Your doctor will talk to you about your results and what they mean. Your rheumatoid factor test result alone isn't enough to diagnose you with any one condition or another. Ask your doctor about any other tests you may need, what they will tell you, and any other next steps.

content_blocks.text: Your doctor will talk to you about your results and what they mean. Your rheumatoid factor test result alone isn't enough to diagnose you with any one condition or another. Ask your doctor about any other tests you may need, what they will tell you, and any other next steps.

sections.heading: Takeaways
content: Rheumatoid factor is a type of antibody that can attack your own tissues and is a sign of autoimmune disease. A rheumatoid factor test, also called an RF test, measures the amount of rheumatoid factor in your bloodstream. Together with your symptoms and other testing, it can help your doctor diagnose you with rheumatoid arthritis or another autoimmune condition. Ask your doctor if you should have an RF test and what your test results mean.

content_blocks.text: Rheumatoid factor is a type of antibody that can attack your own tissues and is a sign of autoimmune disease. A rheumatoid factor test, also called an RF test, measures the amount of rheumatoid factor in your bloodstream. Together with your symptoms and other testing, it can help your doctor diagnose you with rheumatoid arthritis or another autoimmune condition. Ask your doctor if you should have an RF test and what your test results mean.

sections.heading: Rheumatoid Factor Test FAQs
content: A normal RF test result is under 20 units per milliliter of blood.

If your doctor tells you that your rheumatoid factor test is positive, it means that your RF levels are higher than they should be. By itself, it doesn't tell you what condition you have. But it's a clue that you may have rheumatoid arthritis or another autoimmune condition.

Healthy people can have some rheumatoid factor in their blood without having any symptoms. But you don't need rheumatoid factor. A low RF test result may mean you don't have rheumatoid arthritis or another autoimmune condition. But some people with rheumatoid arthritis or autoimmune disease don't have high RF levels, especially if it's early on.

meta_description: If you have rheumatoid arthritis, you may need the rheumatoid factor test to diagnose it. WebMD tells you what you need to know.
